attributes.app_description: This App is for carers providing care for a person with dementia.While it is not possible to cover all potential scenarios, it includes the behaviours most commonly reported by carers. Choose the option that best suits your situation:
attributes.general_details: The physical changes that occur in a person's brain due to dementia can affect their memory, thinking, mood and behaviour. The many other underlying factors that can contribute to behavioural change are often complex and so strategies are never 'one size fits all'. Behaviours may be the person's attempt at communicating their needs when they are no longer able to express these in words.

sub_category.title: What is happening with the person with dementia?

attributes.title: Aggressive behaviours
attributes.description:
Aggressive behaviours in a person with dementia include behaviours that are physically and/or verbally threatening, in response to a situation they are experiencing

**Contact your doctor or closest hospital urgently for advice if you feel that you or others are at risk of immediate physical harm
**

attributes.title: What do these look like in dementia?

sub_section.data:
Hit out at others
Punch, kick or scratch
Push or shove other people or objects
Throw objects
Resist care
Bite or spit

Call out loudly
Say things that are insulting to others
Scream or shout 
Swear or curse
Use offensive or abusive language
Experience increased verbally and/or physically aggressive behaviours in the late afternoon/early evening (sundowning)
Aggressive behaviours can occur if the person with dementia is in pain, feeling unwell or has a fever. Seek medical advice; in the meantime consider relief from pain and fever

For urgent help, if you feel that you or others are at risk of harm
To check if the person has an illness, infection or delirium
To check if the person has pain that they are unable to describe
To check for side effects or a reaction to the person's medication
To check if the person has underlying depression, anxiety, delusions or  hallucinations
To check whether the person could be affected by or withdrawing from alcohol and/or drugs
To check if the person's mouth may be causing them pain and/or whether they need to see a dentist
To check for an allergic reaction that may make the person irritated and/or restless
For information about medications which may help to reduce physically aggressive behaviours if necessary for the safety of the person and/or others
Physical changes to the person's brain due to dementia can make it difficult for them to tolerate, and control their reaction to, everyday situations

The person may be in pain but unable to tell you about it; consider their body language for clues e.g. grimacing, increased confusion, reluctance to move a part of the body
The person may be medically unwell or they may have an infection or fever; discuss symptoms with their doctor

sub_section.sub_heading: The person with dementia may also be:
sub_section.data:
Dehydrated; consider the weather, when they last had a drink and how much they have had to drink in total today
Constipated; consider when they last opened their bowels and if there has been a change in diet e.g. less fibre and/or fluids
Experiencing side effects of medication; consider how long it has been since medications have been reviewed and if there have been any recent changes 
Taking medications that are no longer required; check if they are accumulating and/or taking expired medications 
Hungry and/or thirsty; the person may no longer recognise the body's signals that they need to eat or drink
Mistakenly feeling threatened and needing to defend themselves
Uncomfortable; consider clothing in relation to the weather and their comfort 
Feeling frustrated or pressured because they can no longer cope with everyday demands
Tired because of disturbed sleep at night 
Uncomfortable because their dentures do not fit well and/or may need cleaning; their own teeth may also be causing pain
Feeling alone, abandoned or separated from their primary carer
Feeling unwell and/or agitated due to an allergic reaction
Lonely and/or bored; they may no longer be able to seek company or start activities by themselves
Feeling stressed because they are confused or frightened
Misinterpreting sights and/or sounds due to impaired vision or hearing
Unable to wait for their needs to be met because they lack patience e.g. waiting for a meal in a restaurant or large dining room can cause frustration
Feeling as though their independence is being threatened
Feeling exposed and/or angry due to a lack of privacy e.g. aware of others talking about their personal matters
Feeling embarrassed or humiliated if their dignity is not maintained e.g. values and beliefs that have been important to them in the past are ignored
Physical changes to the person's brain due to dementia can make it difficult for them to understand their surroundings and what is happening around them

sub_section.sub_heading: The person with dementia may also be:
sub_section.data:
Unsettled by changes in their familiar routine, carers and/or surroundings
Distressed/agitated by the actions of others around them
Responding to environmental stressors and/or too much stimulation e.g. noise, lighting, temperature
Feeling confused/agitated due to a lack of familiar people and/or surroundings e.g. in a busy cafÃ©
Overwhelmed because they feel that there are too many people around them 
Finding it difficult to see e.g. if room lighting is insufficient
Feeling trapped, restrained or confined by aspects of their surroundings
Responding to a situation that they find threatening or disturbing e.g. a large mirror
Feeling that they have no personal space
Lacking opportunities for meaningful social interaction
Bored and/or not getting enough stimulation from their surroundings
Physical changes to the person's brain due to dementia can make it difficult for them to express themselves and understand what others say to them

sub_section.sub_heading: The person with dementia may also be:
sub_section.data:
Attempting to communicate their needs via the aggressive behaviours
Unable to focus on what you are saying because they are distracted e.g. by noise, movement, people 
Having difficulty hearing others due to impaired hearing or wax build up
Stressed/frustrated when others misunderstand them
Unable to communicate their needs effectively due to declining language skills
Attempting to communicate in their first language due to increasing difficulty speaking English 
Confused by others' attempts to reason or argue with them
Physical changes to the person's brain due to dementia can make it difficult for them to do the things they could previously manage without help

sub_section.sub_heading: The person with dementia may also be:
sub_section.data:
Unable to get started on a task
Unable to recall all the steps of a task or activity
Having difficulty understanding what they need to do to complete a task or activity
Unable to recognise a task as familiar
Attempting a task with items that are not familiar
Concerned about making mistakes or failing at tasks they previously found straightforward
Unintentionally biting a carer in response to attempts to clean their mouth, teeth and/or dentures

attributes.title: What can you do to help?

sub_section.data:
It is important to know the person's story and find out what has previously been meaningful to them
Identify individual triggers, frustrations and stressors so these can be minimised and/or avoided
Provide structure and routine in the personâ€™s day; reduce the need for them to make decisions that they can no longer manage
Make sure that the person feels safe and comfortable in their surroundings e.g. consider rails and/or a shower chair in the bathroom
Be aware of early signs that the person is becoming upset or irritated; intervene where possible e.g. obvious tension during conversation with others may be forgotten if the person is directed to something of interest elsewhere
Check that glasses and hearing aids are working, fitted correctly and the prescription is current
Make sure the person's mouth, teeth and/or dentures are kept clean; maintain regular dental check-ups
Consider additional non-drug ways to relieve pain such as gentle heat and light massage
Where possible distract the person from a situation which can cause agitation or aggression by offering activities, food and/or company they enjoy
Simplifying the person's clothing may allow them to keep their independence for longer by reducing frustration around dressing and maintaining continence e.g. pull on pants and skirts instead of buttons and zippers
Where there is a risk of injury, keep the person's fingernails trimmed to avoid them scratching themselves or others
Seek advice from health professionals about structured activities such as individualised behavioural therapies
Take steps to maintain the person's dignity e.g. try to maintain their previous standard of dress and grooming
Maintain the person's privacy in relation to personal matters and sensitive information such as mail, bank and legal documentation
Avoid restraining or confining the person as these can lead to an increase in aggressive behaviours

Go to the carer support section for more advice

Modify/simplify the personâ€™s surroundings to support them e.g. clear signage/pictures to indicate the way to the toilet
Develop a structured routine; this can provide a reassuring framework that may help to support and engage the person
Help the person to identify their room as their own space e.g. with items and/or photographs that remind them of loved ones, previous positive experiences and achievements
Maintain familiar routines and carers where possible
The person's surroundings should encourage and support them to participate in everyday activities e.g. warm bathroom in winter, sunny/shady spots in the garden, meal table not cluttered with too many choices 
Consider background noises that may make it difficult for the person to focus e.g. TV, others' conversations, children playing nearby
Where possible, ensure everyday items the person may need can be easily seen
A change of scenery may provide a distraction or ease increasing tension e.g. taking the person for a drive or a walk; N.B. driving with the person who has already reached the point of aggression is not safe and should not be attempted
At times, some forms of stimulation may increase agitation which can lead to aggressive behaviours e.g. their favourite music may be more appropriate than a TV program they can no longer follow
Take steps to protect the person's modesty e.g. close the curtains when assisting with showering and dressing

If strategies are not helping

â€¢ Ensure the person with dementia and others are safe 
â€¢ Take time out from the situation 
â€¢ Supervise them discreetly 
â€¢ If possible try again later 
Go to the carer support section for more advice

Stay mindful of your safety when interacting with the person; do not place yourself in a position of risk e.g. directly in front of them or within arm's reach if there is a possibility of aggression
Approach the person slowly and from a direction that allows them to see you coming; take care not to startle them
Always use your name and explain the purpose of your approach; the person may have forgotten who you are even in a short space of time
Your facial expressions are important e.g. smile and, where appropriate, provide eye contact
While communication with the person should be clear and easy to understand, it is important to approach and speak to them as an adult
Be aware of your tone of voice and body language; these are just as important as the words you use
Make sure your posture and movement is non-threatening e.g. don't stand over them
Speak clearly and calmly without shouting
Use short, simple sentences
Allow extra time for the person to understand what has been said and respond
Provide reassurance that the person is doing OK
Provide non-verbal cues e.g. directing, hand movements 
When the person is having difficulty answering a question, limit the choices and rephrase the question so a yes/no response is possible
Consider gentle touch if appropriate and safe
Include the person in conversation at a level that they feel comfortable
Where the person is repetitive, do not remind them that they have asked you the same question before
Donâ€™t argue or attempt to reason with the person; they may no longer be able to see a different perspective and this can increase stress 
Avoid confrontation; this will emphasise where the person is having difficulty

If strategies are not helping 
â€¢ Stop 
â€¢ Ensure the person with dementia and others are safe
â€¢ Take time out from the situation 
â€¢ Supervise them discreetly 
â€¢ If possible try again later 
Go to the carer support section for more advice

Simplify a task by breaking it down into small/fewer steps; provide clear and brief directions at each step
Ensure the task is undertaken in the most familiar manner possible e.g. showering in the morning or evening according to previous habits
Give pain relief approximately 30 minutes before tasks that may be uncomfortable e.g. showering, dressing
Allow flexibility and extra time to attempt and complete tasks e.g. eating meals, using the toilet
Consider the person's likes and dislikes when trying to engage them in everyday tasks e.g. their favourite music may make them more relaxed during showering
Do not rush the person to complete a task as this may increase their frustration
Try activities which support the personâ€™s current strengths and are meaningful to them e.g. folding clean washing, raking leaves outdoors, outings
Consider the person's current abilities and how they are feeling at the time when planning the duration of an activity; stop before they become agitated or bored
Recognise when the person is feeling tired and avoid attempting tasks they find challenging at these times
If making a decision has become difficult for the person, reduce the choices e.g. show only one item of clothing at a time during dressing, place one plate at a time in front of them when serving meals
Be flexible when assisting with personal care activities e.g. if combing the person's hair prompts aggression, a soft brush may be more comfortable
Provide opportunities for safe walking and/or exercise within the limits of their current state of health if this eases agitation which can lead to aggressive behaviours
Choose your battles carefully; avoid causing the person stress over tasks that can wait until they are more settled and able to cope
Avoid drawing attention to failed attempts

attributes.title: Agitated behaviours
attributes.description: Agitated behaviours in a person with dementia are restless and repetitive behaviours that cause distress and appear to be without purpose, in response to a situation that they are experiencing

attributes.title: What do these look like in dementia?

sub_section.data:
Appear uneasy or tense
Be irritable
Be very restless and unable to sit still
Fidget and/or do things repeatedly
Pace up and down repeatedly
Call out and/or shout
Call out in distress
Undress and/or dress repeatedly
Resist care
Experience increased agitation in the late afternoon/early evening (sundowning)

George has been recently widowed. His family has been increasingly supporting him in his own home since his diagnosis of dementia some years ago. Since their mother's death, George's four daughters have taken turns in staying with him overnight and community care services are visiting three mornings each week.
George's sleeping patterns have become very irregular. He is frequently awake at night and wanders from room to room, turning on the lights, radio and/or television. When his daughters attempt to settle him back to bed they find that their father is very confused and can become agitated. George's family is determined to keep him at home as long as they can, however his nighttime behaviours mean that his daughters are exhausted the next day when they must meet their work and family commitments.
In the mornings George tends to sleep late and finds it difficult to get out of bed for his breakfast and shower when the care workers visit to assist. The community service provider has already rescheduled Georgeâ€™s visits to happen as late as possible.

sub_section.sub_heading: The GP has checked for the following:
sub_section.data:
Â·  Pain/discomfort/illness/infection/constipation that may disrupt George's sleep
Â·  Medication effects: interactions, dosage, recently prescribed, side effects
Â·  Delirium and primary sleep disorders e.g. restless legs syndrome, sleepwalking, sleep apnoea
Â·  General health concerns including blood tests, urine tests and/or cognitive assessment as needed

sub_section.sub_heading: Other potentially contributing factors have been considered:
sub_section.data:
Â·  Disturbances at night from noise, people and/or activities in or around Georgeâ€™s home
Â·  Unsettling changes to Georgeâ€™s routine
Â·  Georgeâ€™s declining ability to effectively communicate his needs/concerns to the family, particularly during the night
Â·  Whether too much is expected of him for his current level of dementia
Â·  Georgeâ€™s reduced ability for coping with stress due to his advancing dementia
Â·  Georgeâ€™s recent loss and ongoing grief in light of his dementia; at times he forgets why his wife isn't in the bed next to him when he stirs at night

sub_section.sub_heading: A health professional has suggested the following strategies:
sub_section.data:
Â·  Observe for triggers that indicate when George is becoming unsettled during the evening prior to bedtime so these situations can be avoided, reduced or managed wherever possible
Â·  Develop a plan for managing Georgeâ€™s disturbed nights so all his daughters can adopt a consistent routine and approach to preparing him for sleep and the nighttime behaviours
Â·  Encourage George to express his needs as far as he is able; allow him sufficient time to communicate
Â·  George's daughters could seek carer education to learn the most effective ways of supporting him and meet other carers for friendship/support
Â·  Seek occasional respite care

Â·  George's bedroom is close to a busy road where obvious traffic noise and headlights continue throughout much of the night; prior to his wife's death he would have rolled over and gone back to sleep if disturbed by these
Â·  George was persuaded to move into a quieter, darker back bedroom; as it faced east, it also received the first morning light which encouraged him to wake earlier
Â·  A small night light in his bedroom and in the bathroom assisted George with orientation when he needed to use the bathroom at night
 Â·  During discussion to develop a plan, George's daughters realised that a television program that had been their father's favourite was now difficult for him to follow and sometimes caused him great frustration; more relaxing activities were offered during the evening 
Â·  Consistent nighttime routines (sleep hygiene) were put in place across George's week; in time a regular bedtime and pattern were established
Â·  While George was still awake at times during the night, the situation was more manageable and less disruptive to both his, and his daughter's daytime activities

"Be alert to the possibility of untreated pain; a person with dementia may be unable to tell you that they are in pain",
"Dehydration can cause confusion; a person with dementia may not recognise the body's signals that they need to drink",
"Seek medical advice promptly if a person with dementia has stopped eating drinking and/or taking prescribed medications",
"Suicidal thoughts or ideas in a person with dementia who is depressed increases their risk of harm; discuss the need for specialist assessment with their doctor",
"If the person with dementia has a plan for how they will commit, seek urgent medical attention"

"Where wandering is a risk, ensure the person has a form of identification with your contact details on them at all times and keep a recent photograph of the person handy should you need to call on emergency services",
"Disrupted sleep and/or wandering at night increases the risk of falls and injury; provide night lights where needed",
"Consider exit alarms or monitoring devices where the person is at risk of wandering into danger; balance their level of independence with the degree of risk",
"Those with apathy or depression in dementia are particularly at risk of neglect when they are unable to express their needs; the risk increases if the person lives alone"
